Edmundus Spenser Londiensis, Anglicorum Poetarum nostri seculi facile princeps, quod eius poemata faventibus Musis & victuro genio conscripta comprobant.  Obiit immatura morte anno salutis 1598, & prope Galfredum Chaucerum conditur qui faelicissime posesin Anglicis literis primus illustravit.  In quem haec scripta sunt Epitaphia.
Hic prope Chaucerum situs est Spenserius, illi</br>Proximus ingenio, proximus ut tumulo.
Hic prope Chaucerum, Spensere poeta, poetam</br>Conderis, et versu quam tumulo proprior.</br>Anglica, te vivo, vixit plautsitque Poetis;</br>Nunc moritura timet, te moriente, mori.

[Next Chaucer's bones sleeps Edmund Spenser's dust in death.</br>In genius each, in tomb, the other nigh;</br>Here near great poet Chaucer, poet Spenser, lie,</br>As near in sepulture, as in poesy.</br>While thou wert living England's muse lived joyauntly;</br>Dying, while thou art dead, she fears to die.]</br>
